The main characters, John Snow and Henry Whitehead, who individually and then together work to solve the mystery, are impressive and engaging. The promoters of the miasmic theory of transmission are given a fair presentation, and the process by which a new scientific model for understanding an ancient disease overcomes a long accepted theory is fascinating (spoiler: people, even clever science-y sorts, aren't always quick to recognize that they've been Wrong, even when the evidence against their beliefs is pretty solid). Johnson is a fine storyteller, and I found this captivating.

In 1854, a cholera outbreak struck the inhabitants of a London neighbourhood. Hundreds died, but two local investigators—a doctor, John Snow, and an Anglican priest, Henry Whitehead—joined forces to disprove the prevalent theory that cholera was spread through "miasma", or noxious smells. Steven Johnson writes well and evocatively, particularly in the early parts of the book where he's laying out the landscape (or I should say particularly the smellscape) of Victorian London, or the state of contemporary medical knowledge. However, there aren't really the sources for this to be a full-length book, it seems, and so as the book wears on Johnson increasingly resorts to tangents. The whole last chapter belongs to an entirely different work, with its speculation about the future of urban life, environmentalism, and... nuclear weapons? The core narrative about Snow, Whitehead, and the impact of the disease itself would make for a great magazine article, but as is, the reader is somewhat inclined to skim as the book wears on—and the dead of Broad Street deserve more than that.

Up until the end, this was a four star read. Then Johnson took the implications of John Snow's work way too far and it just didn't work for me. And given that, in this book, the last two chapters -- out of ten -- focused on that, it's hard to ignore. Other than that, it was an interesting book. I learned all about what cholera does to the body, and let me tell you that it was a bit much at times. I also learned about miasma theory of disease, which is fascinating to me. John Snow was way ahead of his time in many ways and was an impressive man. I mean, he did great work. And he was a man far ahead of his time. By the time his peers could appreciate him and his work, he was gone.

I have been so lucky lately. This book is right up my alley: smart people doing science in history. The story of John Snow ("HE KNOWS SOMETHING!") and Henry Whitehead and the Soho Cholera outbreak was a fascinating of biology, epidemiology, sociology, memes, and epidemiology. I especially liked Johnson's discussion of how science and cities are not only interconnected, but essential to each other. In fact the entire book was great. If I keep finding good books like this to read this summer, I'm going to be a very happy reader.

"This is a story with four protagonists: a deadly bacterium, a vast city, and two gifted but very different men. One dark week a hundred fifty years ago, in the midst of great terror and human suffering, their lives collided on London's Broad Street, on the western edge of Soho."Our son, a writing major at university, recently heard author Steven Johnson speak about his books and on writing. He bought me Johnson's book "The Ghost Map; The Story of London's Most Terrifying Epidemic-- and How it Changed Science, Cities, and the Modern World."Johnson is like a Julia Child of non-fiction, blending history, science, and contemporary issues into an immensely enjoyable and fascinating narrative delicacy. Johnson presents a full background to the events of the 1854 cholera epidemic, covering sanitary conditions, the cholera bacterium and disease, medical theories on disease at the time, and the progression of the epidemic. The two heroes of the book are Dr. John Snow and the Rev. Henry Whitehead. Johnson explains how these men's contributions transformed medicine and science. Dr. Snow's pioneering research on ether and chloroform reached its zenith when he was called to Queen Victoria's bedside to ease the birth of her eight child. Dr. Snow doubted the prevalent medical theory of 'miasma' or odors causing disease. The epidemic in his neighborhood gave him the opportunity to carefully document and study the disease's progression, ending in the formulation the revolutionary theory that the disease was spread from human waste through water.The Rev. Henry Whitehead was the twenty-eight-year old assistant curate in the neighborhood church. He knew the community and the people intimately. Intellectual and affable, the curate saw first-hand the human tragedy of the epidemic. He noted that the households afflicted with the disease did not follow any known 'logical' pattern. The dirtiest (and most odoriferous) houses might be passed, while the house next door was stricken with death.Following these men's investigations is like reading a mystery novel; there is an impetus to keep reading to see how they solve the case. They end up meeting, and eventually, Whitehead was converted to Snow's theory."The Ghost Map" refers to Snow's map of the neighborhood that marked the dead at each house, implicating one central water pump as the source of the epidemic. Next to the pump was the house of the first cholera victim, with a broken cesspool wall that had leaked into the water supply. Snow's work did not immediately revolutionize medical theory. Changing paradigms of thinking require revolutions or a slow dying out of the old ways of thinking. The book concludes with a discussion on cities, their continued growth, and the challenges of post 9/11 problems.Our son also bought "Everything Bad is Good for You," a Millennium Generation's apology for loving video games, television, and all the popular culture entertainment that is often attacked. In brief, entertainment has become more sophisticated over time, more challenging, and hence has expanded our mental abilities. For instance, he compares Classic television shows with their single linear plot line to today's multi-plot continuous story lines found in shows like LOST and MAD MEN. Young adults who grew up with computer or video games needed use more 'brainpower' than those of us who grew up with Candyland and Uno. Whereas contemporary popular culture is usually attacked for it's content, Johnson points out that the skills required are not 'bad for you.'

On August 28, 1854, working-class Londoner Sarah Lewis emptied a bucket of waste water into the cesspool of her squalid apartment building and triggered the deadliest outbreak of cholera in the city's history. A Victorian city with more than 2 million people packed into a ten-mile circumference. This is the story of two men: Dr. John Snow who pioneered the use of ether as an anesthetic in the United Kingdom, and on a personal note, mentions the first medical use of ether by Dr. William Morton; and the Reverend Henry Whitehead, an Oxford-educated young man whose Anglican calling did nothing to abate his fondness for London taverns. The book begins with a description of London as a city of scavengers: bone-pickers, rag-gatherers, pure-finders, dredgermen, mud-larks, sewer-hunters, dustmen, night-soil men, bunters, toshers and shoremen. Against this backdrop of vile and ghastly smells, and in the face of a horrifying epidemic, Snow posited the then radical theory that cholera was spread through contaminated water rather than through miasma, or smells in the air. Against considerable resistance from the medical and bureaucratic establishment, Snow persisted and, with hard work and groundbreaking research, helped to bring about a fundamental change in our understanding of disease and its spread. Johnson weaves in overlapping ideas about the growth of civilization, the organization of cities, and evolution to thrilling effect. This is a multifaceted book incorporating a detective story, an introduction to statistics (math), and a personal history. The Ghost Map is a book that, like the work of Jared Diamond, presents both vivid history and a powerful and provocative explanation of what it means for the world we live in. Unlike Jared Diamond however, Steve Johnson does not load the facts to reach the objective that Diamond would have us believe. From Snow's discovery of patient zero to Johnson's compelling argument for and celebration of cities, this makes for an illuminating and satisfying read. It is not a book for the squeamish however; a vivid description of death from cholera is graphically and terrifyingly detailed. As interesting as the main body of the book is, Johnson ends with an Epilogue, which I believe was probably written well after he finished the telling of Dr. Snow’s story. If, for no other reason, read that chapter, but don’t expect to sleep well again. And when you read a newspaper article about a poultry worker dying in Thailand, think about what would happen if H5N1 were to undergo a single transgenic shift. Now, try to go back to sleep.

The Ghost Map is, in part, an account of a cholera epidemic that took place in London in 1854. I say in part, because the epidemic is really a springboard for a series of discussions. In a sense, this book is the history of an idea: that a disease could be waterborne.Back in 1854, this idea was startling, and unacceptable to most of the medical and administrative establishment. Johnson does a good job of highlighting the work of two men, John Snow (who did a lot of the thinking that led to the understanding of how the epidemic grew) and Henry Whitehead, who confronted the disease at street level, talking to the survivors and collecting much of the informal data that helped Snow test his theories.I found it very interesting to read about the struggle that Snow had with the proponents of the "miasma theory," the prevailing wisdom of the time. Back then, people believed that diseases were spread by smells traveling through the air; I've read a lot of Dickens, so I'm well acquainted with the notion of pestilential or noxious air. The fact that this belief seems so ridiculous to us now is evidence of the inroads science has made into our lives.I had never really thought about the seismic shift that occurred when science began to understand nature at the microscopic level. And I had never given much thought to the correlation between clean water and the expansion of cities to the multi-million-headcount levels that are normal to us today. So on the whole, The Ghost Map was a pretty enlightening book. It's written in an easy to read style, and is a page-turner in its way.The book ends with an extensive consideration of urbanization and what it means to mankind. I'm not sure whether this enhances the central story, or detracts from it. It's interesting, in its way, but in the end it's only speculation--and speculation is endless. So the end of the book seemed, well, endless. I probably could have stopped reading at around page 217.Still, on the whole this was an interesting book, and I'm glad I finally read it.

Book blurb: In a triumph of multidisciplinary thinking, Johnson illuminates the intertwined histories and interconnectedness of the spread of disease, contagion theory, the rise of cities, and the nature of scientific inquiry, offering both a riveting history and a powerful explanation of how it has shaped the world we live in. At 20.0% An interesting side effect of reading about cholera is that I'm constantly thirsty.At 40.0%: Unlike Jon Snow from GOT, this John Snow knows something!I listened to the audiobook which is wonderfully narrated by Alan Sklar.Oh the things we take for granted in this part of the world: clean water (well, maybe not in Flint), sewage pipes, epidemiology and the understanding of disease pathways. It's easy to forget that much of the world is not as lucky, and that not that long ago cholera outbreaks wiped out a significant percentage of the populations affected.I love narrative non-fiction books that combine science, medicine, history and still read like a thriller. Over the past several years I've become fascinated by contagious diseases, their origins, how they spread, how we reduce (or not) the mortality rates and this book is another piece of the mosaic. I was fascinated, educated, horrified, and filled with admiration for the two men, one of science and one of the cloth, who solved the puzzle of the cholera outbreak in London in 1854. Each and every one of us living in an urban area today owe a debt of gratitude to these two men.There are so many topics covered in this one book, and I really enjoyed reading about and pondering the implications of the sheer number of humans on the planet and what might be in store for us. The only reason I docked a star was because there was quite a bit of repetition and the epilogue contains the author's opinions on bio-terrorism and nuclear policies, both of which while important seemed completely out of context in this book. Better editing would have resolved these issues.

This book is not about human poop, though he is talking a lot about it. It's about smart people and triumph of modern (for 1854) science and medicine over people who believe in different kind of bull-shit (no pun intended). I liked it a lot, some pages will make you happy with your life here in 2019, just consider that life expectancy for kids was around 14 years, regular adult - around 23-24 and if you highly educated high society gentleman or lady - you better finish all your stuff around 45th birthday since you have less and less chances to see sun next morning. It's about cruel medical practices when surgeon takes 2-3 minutes to amputate you leg or hand. It's about families that lives so close together that density of population is like 10-20 times higher than modern Manhattan.I know I wouldn't want to live in such world (which was just merely 165 years ago). If you long for time of Victorian ladies and gentleman, drinking tea at 5 o'clock in rose garden - please do yourself a favor, read this book. It will tell you how great Victorian world was, that even Queen Victoria gave births to 7 kids without any anesthesia, only on 8th kid she got some ether from John Snow (main character of the book) to easy her birth pain. And who said you would be high society guy or gal? Read about people who make their living by gathering all kind of people waste, you may be born one of them if you lived there.Great book, not just talking on cholera break-out (you can spend 20 minutes in Wikipedia to read all related to it). It shows you what was a society, population, medicine/science, living and dying conditions in Victorian's London in 1854.

3.5 stars. In 1854 the Soho neighborhood of London had an outbreak of Cholera. Within 3 days 127 people in the neighborhood would die. By the end of this outbreak 616 people died from the infection. This outbreak is notable because it lead to a breakthrough in learning how cholera spread. At the time it was thought to have spread through the air, a belief brought about by London's famous and unbearable stench. The Rev. Henry Whitehead and Dr. John Snow (he actually knew quite a bit) worked together, talking to the people living in the neighborhood and tracking the illness, and put together a new theory. The water was contaminated. Their hard work and theories would lead to the development of the London sewer system, and some of their mapping techniques were the early versions of the geolocation technology that we use every day when we google "Nearby restaurants" on our smart phones.The author can be a bit dense, but the information is fascinating. I love how he was able to tie an epidemic more than 150 years ago to modern urban planning, water quality, population density discussions, alcohol tolerance, and technology that was just starting when he wrote the book 10 years ago. I just found it fascinating. And he managed to write an entire book about cholera without once using the word "shit." Rather impressive.

This was an excellent account of the (successful) efforts of two men, John Snow and Henry Whitehead, to understand the means by which cholera is transmitted, following an 1854 outbreak in London's Soho district. The "ghost map" constructed by Snow, and the identification of the index case by Whitehead, were eventually successful in displacing the prevailing "miasma theory" by establishing linkage beyond reasonable doubt to contamination at a single water pump (the Broad Street pump).Johnson does an excellent job of providing a tightly-constructed account of the events during, and immediately following, the week when the epidemic was at its height. He is also very effective in placing the two men's discovery in historical context, and in giving a broader perspective on its significance. An absorbing account of a milestone in epidemiology, at a level of scholarship that far surpasses that of the other work by this author that I had read "Everything Bad is Good for You". I highly recommend this book. Likely to be of most interest to readers who enjoy history, or with an interest in epidemiology or urban development.

I think the only slightly disappointing thing about this book was that I'd already read a really good article on the topic, and so I found that I knew more of the story than I thought I did. But that's not the book's fault. Fascinating stuff.

Fascinating history of the race to stop a major Cholera outbreak in 1854 London, made all the more difficult by the prevailing, completely inaccurate, miasmatic theory of contagion. A triumph of scientific research and deep local knowledge, the cause was found and contained even though no one yet knew of the microbe that causes the disease. The narrative is a bit repetitive, but all in all a solid read.

A very informative account of the London 1850s cholera outbreak. The author presents the facts well and rounds them of with well-placed literary examples from Dickens. There are good comparatives with evolutionary biology on how a society functions.All in all a very important book and quite commendable.

"Cholera is fascinating!" I said to my partner multiple times while reading, so I suppose that's my review: Cholera is fascinating, or rather the relationship between social structures, social practice/knowledge, and disease is fascinating. Johnson has an unexpectedly present voice, opinionated and even chiding as he focuses on central figures of cholera research while knocking down the great man theory and placing them, and their discoveries and achievements, within that same social context. It's specific, clearly-drawn, interconnected, compelling--and frustrating, sometimes for the wrong reasons.Namely the epilogue, which segues into a disjointed, overreaching "what now?" that looks to the future of relationships between society and disease. It's bleakly hilarious to read during the COVID-19 pandemic, because all the theorycrafting about maps and the power of the internet is rendered obviously ridiculous--while the underlying thesis about the social element of a disease, which remains heartbreakingly pertinent, is nearly buried.

Likes: Throughout history, there have been some extremely brave people. The doctors and cholera investigators in this book should definitely be put in the “extremely brave” category. In 1850s London, no one knew what caused the cholera outbreak. People were either dying in droves or frantically trying to escape the city. A few researchers ignored their instinct to run from the disease. They ventured deeper into London to find the cause of cholera. I enjoyed reading the stories of the investigators and how they methodically uncovered the way the disease spread.I think the moral of this book is to not cling so tightly to your ideas that you ignore or dismiss anything that doesn’t fit with your worldview. You could be missing something important. In the 1800s, scientists believed that cholera came from bad-smelling air. They refused to listen to any alternate theories. By refusing to be open-minded, they did a lot of damage to humans and to the environment. Even though the London cholera outbreak happened a long time ago, modern people can still learn from it.“Superstition, then and now, is not just a threat to the truth. It’s also a threat to national security.” – The Ghost MapDislikes: I only like narrative nonfiction. I hate reading textbooks. From the synopsis, this book sounds narrative, like it has a plot. The author does tell the story of the cholera researchers, but the plot is broken up by long, tedious chapters about sewer construction and city planning. I got bored enough that I skimmed parts of it.The Bottom Line: I wanted to read about people solving a scientific mystery. The mystery turns out to be only a small part of the book. The rest of it is a textbook. I was mostly bored.I have a blog! Check it out if you like reviews, giveaways, and bookish nonsense.

Although some people might not find this a page-turning read, the public health and infectious disease geek in me did. I'd already known about John Snow's epidemiologic prowess in London's mid-nineteenth-century cholera outbreak and its ties to the Broad Street Pump. I even visited the site of the pump on a trip to London. I did not, however, know about the amount of resistance he got from the public health board of the day. Their insistence on miasma (bad air) as the cause for the outbreak, and essentially all outbreaks, certainly contributed to a number of deaths. Smelly air made you sick was their thought. I also did not know about Henry Whitehead, a local clergyman whose ties with the community and amateur epidemiologic sleuthing aided John Snow in his discovery. Both men played a significant role in connecting cholera to contaminated water. It seems obvious to us now, but back then, when so many professionals believed bad air was the cause of disease, the two men had their work cut out for them.There's lots of talk about poo and waste and noxious smells in this book. If you don't mind that, and you enjoy historical accounts of public health and disease theory, then you'll probably like this book. Near the end, there is also a discussion by the author on urbanization and population growth. Some of the book is scattered timewise, and there are a few dull bits, but that didn't lessen my enjoyment of it.

"It's true enough that the Victorians were grappling with heady issues like utilitarianism and class consciousness. But the finest minds of the era were also devoted to an equally pressing question: What are we going to do with all of this shit? The extent of London's excrement problem was universally agreed upon."This is fascinating history; why didn't we learn interesting history like this in school? Cholera epidemics broke out periodically in London; this book is about the 1854 epidemic and how the scientists started to understand that all disease wasn't caused by miasma, but that cholera was a waterborne disease contracted when the waste of a cholera victim was ingested through sewage in water supplies. I couldn't get enough of this book, SO interesting, written in a very accessible and entertaining way. I would very much like to read Steven Johnson's other books. Recommended

An insightful synthesis of the 1854 Broad Street cholera outbreak, how it was brought about by the changing city conditions of that era, and how the debate over its cause involved competing scientific methods endemic to that time. Johnson evidently takes great enjoyment in tying together the threads of the story from the molecular level (how does cholera thrive in the small intestine?) to the level of a city (how does cholera thrive in a neighborhood?). Unfortunately, he gets overenthusiastic and offers a lumpy, excessively long epilogue on the perils of modern city living. The book is at its best when Johnson colorfully illustrates Victorian slum life and Dr. John Snow's dogged efforts to trace cholera's spread from street to street.

This book was thoroughly planned and executed. The information was explained and presented well. It often felt like a novel as the author replayed the historical aspects. I appreciated the author’s research and attention to detail. Finally, I appreciated that the author didn’t stray from the topic at hand which seems to be a common occurrence in many of the science-based books I’ve been reading. I learned much.
Very interesting and a fast read. Recommended.

The story of John Snow and Henry Whitehead proving that cholera was spread by contaminated water and not by contaminated air is both exciting and important reading. On one level The Ghost Map is an gripping detective story with the embattled Snow tracking down evidence to make his case. On another level it is about human psychology and just how hard it is for people to struggle against confirmation bias and change deeply rooted beliefs. In the right hands this book would make a good movie.Johnson writes about Victorian London with a Dickensian grittiness that I enjoyed, and he also discusses the important impact that Snow’s ideas have in the modern world. He’s never boring.

London in the 1800s was utterly disgusting. You cram two million people and sundry livestock into one Victorian city, add stinky professions such as tanners and renderers, and then put them all on top of all the crap two million people produce, and no sewage system to put it in, it's going to stink. And stink powerfully.Clearly, something had to be done. Unfortunately, the leaders of the city picked the wrong thing to do. They decided to clean up the city by funneling all the waste into the Thames, which, by the way, was the source of drinking water for much of the city. See a problem?The Thames went from being a clean river full of salmon and other fish, to a stinking cesspool of murky water in about 20 years.At the same time, diseases such as cholera were spreading more quickly, thanks to improvements in transportation. London was perfectly set up to have an outbreak - it was just a matter of time.And when the outbreak hit, jumping the channel from Hamburg to London in 1853, it hit hard and fast. So hard that even though they couldn't see the cholera bacteria yet, they could see its footprints through the ferocity of the attack. It became possible to trace the source of the disease - if you bothered to look, and didn't just blame it on the stink, or miasma, which was what the leading authorities of the time did. It was up to an iconoclastic doctor and a local clergyman, both of whom were from the neighborhood struck by the cholera outbreak, to study the patterns of who got sick and who didn't, and map it, to uncover the true source.Their efforts were so conclusive and irrefutable that it couldn't be pooh-poohed by the miasmatists, and it eventually led to new sewer system being installed throughout London. The principals of their methods - applying scientific principals to carefully gathered data, and mapping it out, instead of falling back on superstition and assumption - are still being used today.The tale of the outbreak and the investigators was horrifying and fascinating to read about, and the first part of the book went quickly. But when the author started to draw conclusions, he didn't know when to stop. Again and again, the reader was informed of the virtues of applying local knowledge in scientific ways. And then, after drilling that into the readers' heads, the author then switched to speculation about possible outbreaks in the future. And not just from disease, but also from terrorist attacks and nuclear bombs. I guess because the focus is not really on cholera here, but on how population density makes it possible for both disease and for bombs to kill way more people at once.But at the same time, we're told, cities are GOOD, because of the efficient ways energy is used in them. People need less energy to heat and cool their homes, to get to and from work, etc. Things at the end of this book just got a little scattered in focus, and repetitious. I alternated between being bored and intrigued. I could tell the author had done a lot of research on the cholera outbreak, but not spent as much time deciding which conclusion he wanted to draw from it - so he included every thought he'd had about it.Worth a read, this book really made me grateful for the modern plumbing and sewage systems I have access to.

After I finished reading the book, I gave a silent prayer to thank God that I live in the time and place that I do (early 21st century US). I have read a lot of books lately about sanitation, its history, the current status in undeveloped countries and possible methods of improvement. The Ghost Map is the story of 1850’s London, when raw sewage was being pumped directly into the Thames River and then pumped back out again to provide drinking water to millions of people. As one would expect, illness and death soon followed. But why? What was causing the issues? At this time, science had yet to discover microbes and so most great minds of the time blamed the air. Which in retrospect seemed to be self-evident. “The Great Stink” which enveloped London during this time is famous. Read any book or memoirs set in London in the mid eighteenth century and every one will contain a comment on the smell. Before the sewage was pumped into the river, it built up in basements, streets, etc. It was not uncommon for a basement to build up with 4-5 feet of raw human waste. The smell must have been unbearable. So, the air theory made sense. It wasn’t until Dr. John Snow begin applying a scientific method to determine the root cause that water was identified as the source of the illness cholera. Cholera is an unforgiving disease. After consuming the tainted water, a person could be dead within 24 hours (some hung on for days). An outbreak could kill hundreds if not thousands in a week’s time. And as quickly as it comes, it disappears. Scientists and governmental officials of the time blamed fetid air, especially the air in the poorer sections of London. It was felt that poverty and cholera went hand in hand. Dr. Snow changed all that. A humble man who became a doctor to Queen Victoria (he applied the chloroform used in the birth of one of her last children); Dr. Snow had an immense curiosity coupled with a dedication to the “scientific method”. He set out to find how the illness was being spread. Using the mortality rate schedules, he was able to create a map which showed the houses where the deaths had been the worse and drawing upon his knowledge of the area, eventually determined the source was a public water pump. The most fascinating part of the story which help sealed his discovery was the death of a woman much further outside the “hot zone”. When he discovered that she grew up in the infected area and preferred the water from the pump in question, he knew he had discovered the source. The handle came off the pump and the disease stopped in its tracks. Acceptance gradually grew until within twenty years there were no more reported cases of cholera in Great Britain.I found the story fascinating and the author widens the view, discussing sanitation, scientific methods, contagion theories, etc. Using the cholera epidemic as a starting point, the reader is invited to see the broader implications of disease control and how cities in particular can be impacted. I highly recommend the book!

I vaguely knew the story of how removing a pump handle stopped a cholera epidemic, but this book goes into a fascinating level of detail.Cholera was one of the big terrifying diseases of the 1800s—as the author notes, you just had to live with the knowledge that, no matter how healthy you were, at any point you (and your entire family) could be wiped out in a day and a half and no one knew how to stop or prevent it. Cholera moves shockingly fast by basically causing the body to expell all of its water in a messy, nasty, fantastically painful and scary way to die. We know now that it's a water-bourne disease that can be best treated by rapid rehydration, but for a long time, scientists were convinced that, like malaria, cholera was caused by bad smells. So it took a lot of courage, both physical and moral, to map a particularly virulant outbreak and then stand up to scientific orthodoxy and declare that the cause of the outbreak was a single pump. It would take awhile for the declaration to finally be accepted. (Meanwhile, New York would go on a massive anti-cholera clean-up that, while it targeted entirely the wrong thing, removed most of the shit from the streets and made the city as a whole enormously more healthy. For once, bad science had good results.)This is a fascinating book, if you're into this kind of thing. Towards the end, it starts to drift oddly, musing on the modern nature of cities and disasters and such in a way that implies the author had some opinions he wanted to get off his chest and nowhere better to put them. They're interesting, if so tangential to the topic as to be irrelevant. But despite this lack of discipline (perhaps the book felt too short?), it's a good read.

This is a cross-disciplinary study of a problem solved, in 1854, by cross-disciplinary thinking. It's also a wonderful snapshot of Victorian London, a meditation on the urbanization of our species, a jeremiad against belief-based reasoning (his specific target is the belief in "miasma"--that theory that disease was transmitted by smell--that led to the city of London choosing to dump its raw sewage directly into the Thames and thus did crusaders for public health cause the devastating cholera epidemics of the mid nineteenth century, but he makes the parallel with Intelligent Design explicit, too), and several other things. It's also beautifully written; the prose is both lucid and entertaining. (My favorite line: "It's true enough that the Victorians were grappling with heady issues like utilitarianism and class consciousness. But the finest minds of the era were also devoted to an equally pressing question: What are we going to do with all of this shit?") Because Johnson is a cross-disciplinarian, he understands how to use fiction as a primary source (an undertaking which has gotten the better of many otherwise excellent historians--and, of course, the reverse is, if possible, even more true), and thus won my undying devotion. Also, he has hit upon an elegant solution to the problem of writing a scholarly book for a popular audience. No footnotes or numbered endnotes to disrupt the flow of thought and words as you're reading, but if you want to know, the endnotes are there, labeled with page number and the relevant phrase. And he's got his bibliography back there, too.This is an excellent book, and--perhaps bizarrely for a book about a horrifying epidemic--it made me feel both happy and more optimistic than usual about our species.

I really lucked out this semester in my Cities & Health course by getting a chance to read The Ghost Map by Steven Johnson. The book, both a thrilling jaunt into the past and a terrifying look at the possibilities of the future, centers on 1854 London during the city's worst Cholera outbreak. The book follows a unorthodox Doctor, Dr. John Snow, and a man with his ear to the streets, Reverend Henry Whitehead, in the Golden Square neighborhood in Central London. The book chronicles the doctor's challenge in proving that Cholera was (and is) a waterborne disease during a time when popular theory was that diseases were passed from one person to another and epidemics spread through the air. Now this book won't be for everyone, clearly, as the book's central focus is on Cholera, a disease that makes you pour from both ends until there's nothing left. Literally. No bones about it, London sounds like a terrifyingly disgusting place to live back in the 1800s.Eventually Dr. Snow has his day and Cholera is proven as a waterborne disease. There is much more to be learned from the book besides how diseases are spread, and that is what we focused the beginning of the semester on. It also tells the story about how cities were formed, the birth of infrastructure, the birth of sanitation, and much more. I highly recommend this book to those without a weak stomach who are eager for a Non-fiction.

I was intrigued during most of it, but by the last chapter I was bored. I’m not sure where I lost interest. It’s good in some places, but I was left with a sense of “meh” by the end.He ends with a long Conclusion and then an Epilogue where he touches on tentatively-connected subjects — epidemics, electronic maps, technology, urbanization, emergency services, public health services, global warming, terrorism, energy use, population growth, developing countries. You’d think he wrote the book just so he could spout his ideas about these things.Quote:“Hall’s instructions for his cholera committee offer a brilliant case study in how dominant intellectual paradigms can make it more difficult for the truth to be established, even if the people involved are smart, and attentive, and methodical in their research.”Oh, how these words apply in more ways than Johnson would ever care to admit.Similar titles would be Very, Very, Very Dreadful: The Influenza Pandemic of 1918 or Influenza: The Hundred-Year Hunt to Cure the Deadliest Disease in History.

This book was fantastic! It read more like a novel than a medical history. It was how these two men started out from opposite points and came to the same conclusion. It is also interesting to read of a time period so different from ours. I kept wanting to tell the people to wash their hands or instruments. The book starts out slowly with more information on cholera and London than you think you want to know, but it is necessary to understand just how little they knew about the spread of the disease. I have to think back to how we felt when AIDS burst on the scene. No one knew how it passed from person to person. A friend of mine was one of the earliest researchers of the disease and he wanted to study AIDS because so many of the early researchers were contracting it. He went on to be one of the foremost experts on the disease and, in a way, became very much like Dr. Snow. Unlike most historical mysteries, this book wraps everything up very much like Miss Marple. The doctor is finally able to reach back to patient "0" and everything clicks into place. It is unbelievable how strong Dr. Snow was as he went against the "misama" theory of infection. What better way to finish up 2017 reading than with a book on the 1854 London cholera epidemic? It works much better than I thought it would.This is terrific book on the efforts of two men to understand the causes of a cholera outbreak in the Soho area of London in 1854. What made this especially difficult is that the bacterial basis of diseases was not understood at all, the specific details of cholera were unknown, and medical research as we have come to known it did not exist, and medical practice itself was not well developed. With that in mind, the prevailing stories about cholera focused on problems in the air and very frequently tracked longstanding class biases. Add to this that cholera is a terrifying disease (see the book for details) that killed its victims rapidly and the drama of this story can be easily understood. This is a fascinating story which makes me never want to go back to the “good old days”.The book is valuable on several levels. It is first of all a scientific detective story in which one can easily root for the good guys to succeed. It is more than that, however, and one is left to marvel how large metropolitan areas that we take for granted in the West — ever became viable places where people could thrive and not fall victim to epidemics, famines, or other natural and social catastrophes. At the start of the 1800s, the life expectancy in Britain was likely below 40. Today it is closer to double that. This means that a lot more people are in effect living twice as long. Events such as those in this book are among the reasons for the elongation of life spans and the improved standard of living in the West. As the author notes towards the end of the book, megacities in the developing world are coming to dwarf most large Western metropolitan areas and are places where public health that we have come to take for granted cannot be asssumed to be present. Cholera is still around and new outbreaks are highly likely. This story is relevant today and we should not take our public health for granted.The story provides a nice case study of how science progresses and how old theories are replaced by new ones eventually. The follow up in the book about the development of the London sewer and water systems is especially informative. This is relevant in the US as well. As the author notes the reversal of the direction of the Chicago River was prompted by a cholera outbreak. As Gordon’s recent book on the American standard of living shows convincingly, some of the greatest bang for the buck in US economic history came from the development of effective infrastructure, including public water and sewer systems.The Ghost map also has implications for the value of different sorts of knowledge. The case was important for some famous representations of the outbreak on local maps in order to understand the spread of cases and especially deaths. The author makes a strong case that this was not just a simple matter of mapping but more an example of making good use of “local knowledge”. The key breakthrough came when Reverend Whitehead made good use of his knowledge of the neighborhood to understand how the outbreak developed and which theories to support about the outbreak. This has all sorts of implications for information dynamics today. To sell this, consider how life on the internet changed for users when GPS data became from available after 2000. A general search of the web can now be augmented with a localized search tied to various mapping functions. ... and the rest is internet history. That’s right - a connection between mapping cholera in 19th century London and finding out the best route to work with an application like Waze. This interplay of generalized versus local knowledge is a major aspect data work today and it is fascinating to see how such issues developed with 19th century tools and sensibilities and before the growth of modern science.I don’t want to draw out all the potential story lines and perhaps Johnson tries to do a bit much with this case. It is a first rate story, however, and well worth reading. This book has been around for a few years but it fit in well with recent books on the Spanish Flu and Tuberculosis. Disease histories are not for everyone, but if you are up to it, this is a fine book.

General thoughts  I would definitely recommend this book to anyone with an interest in world history and the beginnings of public health and medicine.The Ghost Map is an all-encompassing historical narrative about the cholera outbreaks in London 150 years ago which laid the foundation of epidemiology. This story illustrates cholera from the cellular to global scale surrounding the London outbreak of 1854. The Ghost Map  mainly discusses how the setting in London and the unique attributes of John Snow and Reverend Whitehead enabled them to make an incredible discovery amidst incredible adversity.Since the concept of combining the scientific methods medicine and public health consumes my thoughts, this book was incredibly enjoyable. Something unmentioned, but noteworthy, is that Cholera still affects 3-5 million people every year, despite the fact that cholera was essentially extinguished from London 140 years ago.I wished that the book would offer some of the maps that Dr. Snow created during his research. For those interested, here's a good source: http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia... The Ghost Map – Synopsis 	This book begins by illustrating London’s attempt to be sanitary and sustainable by managing its waste through night-soil men. These workers weren’t only removing human excrement from cesspools; they were recycling it, making the surrounding farmland more fertile and capable of supporting the London population. However, as the city grew, waste management became more difficult and expensive, leading to an inevitable rise of unsanitary conditions and Cholera outbreaks.	The first few chapters illustrates the city of London at the time – from the presence great minds like Mozart and Dickens to the unavoidable smell of human excrement and decaying bodies. London's population explosion caused it to flourish and decay at the same time. The first chapter ends with the death of a baby who had caught Cholera, foreshadowing an inevitable outbreak.	Though London at the time was the largest city in the world, explanatory models for disease were still medieval. Cholera was blamed on the putrid smell of London, the miasma theory. This theory was well accepted by medical professionals and government officials despite the fact that there was no statistical data proving it. Yet, the miasma theory held for untold years, until a critical thinking doctor, John Snow, attempted to solve the case. 	As a groundbreaking anesthesiologist, John Snow understood the dynamics of gases and saw that the spread of cholera couldn’t possibly fit the miasma model. For instance, sewer workers seemed incredibly healthy despite breathing supposedly noxious fumes on a daily basis. However, the miasma theory was deeply engrained belief in London’s society. The 1854 outbreak described in this book was the perfect storm, giving John Snow much needed statistical evidence and credibility that would not only shed light on cholera's etiology, but also launch a new way of thinking about health, epidemiological research, and taking practical measures to prevent disease.

It's probably because I read it immediately after catching up on vastly superior works by Eric Larson, but this is not a terribly compelling book, and it disappointed the heck out of me. Little more than an expanded college thesis--an evolution to which the author admits in his afterward--this is about 150 pages longer than it needs to be. The tone set by its lack of characterization and focus on dry historical facts outstays its welcome about 20 pages in.While it's interesting to note some of the things going on here, the last 80+ pages are nothing more than generic musings on urbanization, the expansion of civilized society, and what pandemics might mean and look like in the future. It's no stretch to say that I could feasibly sit down right now and write in a similar vein on pretty much any subject with which I am familiar. Was there no one editing this before it went to print?Oh, and the best part is, the titular "map" is never once referred to as a "ghost map", and although it is described in elaborate and loving detail, *the book DOES NOT CONTAIN A COPY OF THIS MAP*. WTF? Could be that I had the Kindle edition, but that only makes the omission the more glaringly inexplicable.Also, I'd estimate that at least 25% of the actual text of the book (not counting the vacant fluff about urbanization that comprises the Epilogue) is plagiarized--oh, I mean, quoted. When every chapter contains several multi-page quotations, you're either too enamored of the source material to invoke it in an interesting manner, or you're too destitute for ideas of your own that you simply crib extant work and hope nobody notices. The worst part is, Johnson clearly loves his Dickens as one of his few means of characterizing Victorian slumdwellers, but more often than not he assumes the reader not only has read Dickens extensively, but can recall key passages from memory.My biggest disappointment, however, is the lost opportunities. Someone with less of a singular focus on disease and more of a focus on economics may have made more of the topic. Johnson leads off with a great description of the various strata of improvised filth-raking, but then abandons the entire concept for the rest of the book. This is where Larson shines by comparison--characterizing two interweaving narratives in a manner that makes even the driest subject compelling. Nothing approaching that to be found here, unfortunately.All in all, probably not worth your time, except as a means to underscore how adept even the weakest Larson is by contrast.

"Ghost Map" : Take Two When I initially read Steven Johnson's "Ghost map" a few years back, I was either young and impressionable or I skipped parts. I'm betting on the latter. In looking for something while trying out my library's eAudio selections (their non-fiction is poor), I decided to reread "Ghost map." The first half (and some of the conclusion) was as interesting as I remembered (as interesting as you can get when talking about disease and death) and I would recommend it. As other reviewers have pointed out the author does have a slightly annoying habit of repeating himself - which during the first half I could forgive. The author also tends to meander between topics (before returning to the story of the outbreak) which personally I don't mind (and which I love when it's done well), but could be off-putting to others expecting a straight-forward account. I would also recommend the book as opposed to the audio. I hated the narration. The reader spoke too fast and at times was monotone. But what drove me nuts was that he (as an apparent non-British speaker) would start a quote with a British accent, but halfway through the accent would disappear. There were also sections where a quote would end and the author begin, but it wasn't clearly delineated during the reading. In my opinion, skip the conclusion and the epilogue. The latter was especially painful. Johnson only mentions the importance of the map (which I was ignorant of, being only an occasional popular science reader) during his conclusion. It would have been more helpful (and interesting) as a said layman reader, for him to have brought out the importance of the map (and hence the title of his book) earlier, or (better yet) earmarked an entire chapter to it's legacy. Instead, the reader has to wade through a muddled theory of how city life is better for us and the environment, despite terrorists (the twin tower deaths were no big deal, btw)* and a super flu. Though I live in a fairly large city, and it's convenient and useful (and while I will probably remain in a city for the remainder of my life, I'm not particularly attached to city life), I find his constant "city is everything" methodology annoying (and cities without green space, really?)*While that's not what Johnson said or meant, the way he phrased that section made it seem as if he were belittling (not in the sense of making light of, but more brushing aside) the loss of human life. This is my opinion of his writing - you may see it differently.

“What in the world can we do with all of this shit?” That was the question of the day for two million 19th century Londoners. The night soil men proved ill equipped to keep up with removing the volumes of human excrement overflowing from cesspools and rising in basements of the Soho and Golden Square neighborhoods. It was clear London needed a new sewage system.  Opening the pages of this most impressive account of sleuthing the source of the cholera outbreak was simply fascinating. Reverend Henry Whitehead and Dr. John Snow, two strangers of different backgrounds, joined together by circumstance shared valuable information and expertise. Independently each spent countless of hours interviewing, recording, and analyzing all collected data. The scientific mind of Dr. Snow compiled a map indicating the location and number of deaths therein. Whitehead as a trusted, respected local was key in turning the made up minds of city agencies who stubbornly clung to the idea the disease originated in the foul, smelly air to accepting the actual catalyst for the outbreak. This is really an outstanding detective story very well told. A history lesson if you will. The facts, players and uncanny elusiveness of this indiscriminate killer called cholera progressed systematically without the bog down of boring statistics. The author skillfully carries history into our modern times with glimpses into our foreseeable future. A notable writing achievement.

Although I expected a book about the bubonic plague, this is about a cholera outbreak in London in 1854. It's an interesting story, partly about the cholera outbreak, more about the development of the scientific method and medical science.Unfortunately, Johnson is no Erik Larsen (Devil in the White City), Bill Bryson (A Short History of Nearly Everything), or even Simon Winchester (A Crack in the Edge of the World). The bones of a suspenseful, intense, exciting story were there, but the writing doesn't make the most of the facts.The actual content of the book was good (albeit not exciting). But then you get to the epilogue, and it becomes clear that Johnson wrote the book solely so he could stick his epilogue on the end. It appears to be a master's thesis or PhD thesis proposal that attempts a medico-scientific apologia for dense urbanization. I am unquestionably a city mouse, but am uneasy in some ways to be so removed from the food producing system. I guess the point was to assuage the fears of urban dwellers that we are bad for the planet, but it didn't do much for me. The discussion of nuclear attacks and biological attacks was odd, and the complete absence of mention of chemical/poison attacks was a big hole. The epilogue was altogether random and clearly had an agenda and diminished the book in my mind.

This is really my favorite type of book so I'd have to say I'm probably a bit partial on the one hand, on the other hand I've read quite a few epidemiologically inclined books and they all have to stand up to the scrutiny of comparison. I can hardly believe I was able to finish this extremely dull literary tour-de-snooze. Apparently the author thinks twenty times might be sufficient. This whole thing brought to mind very fleshed out papers in which college students ran out of words well before they should have and merely reiterated former statements with more emphasis. After a while I knew the book would get no better but I was halfway through and I wanted to be sure this book deserved every ill word I would write about it, and I can say without hesitation that it surely does.

This book is about shit. Well, more precisely it's about how the lack of proper sewage systems in Victorian London led to the 1854 outbreak of cholera in which 500 people died in less than two weeks within a only a few blocks. But more than that, it's the story of the birth of epidemiology through John Snow's work to trace the outbreak back to the Broad Street water pump. It's a fascinating story that's equal parts medical history, epidemiology, and philosophy. It's definitely not one for the sqeamish (I mean, there are people literally shitting themselves to death all over the place), but it's a detailed examination of the struggles that Snow - and his subsequent investigative partner, Henry Whitehead - went through in trying to get their theory heard and accepted. There's an entire section at the end dedicated to how dramatically different a major epidemic would be today compared to Victorian London. And there's a section on the impact that cities have had on the world, and how the birth of supercities continues to impact society. Basically, it's really readable despite all the people dying of cholera, and it's incredibly interesting. Go read it. Unless you're squeamish or prone to hypochondria. Then maybe don't...

Johnson is most at home at recalling the Victorian descriptions of the giant monster that was their metropolitan London. And he's okay with the science. But he struggles with crafting a narrative out the story of the Broad Street Pump and John Snow's and Henry Whitehead's contributions in forwarding the contamination theory of cholera - and don't get me wrong: it's a great story. Unfortunately Johnson seems to lose steam with these particular characters about halfway through the book and repeats the same points about the scientific method and the beautiful magical power of cities. This is also the topic of the last hundred pages, which become Johnson's TED-Talk soapbox moment on how wonderful New York is (delicatessens!) and how urbane urban folks are (theater!) and how bad terrorists (9/11!) and nuclear bombs are (boo, hiss!). You can feel free to skip that part.Also, for a book all about the power of a good infographic, the book is woefully deficient in them. The titular ghost map doesn't appear until the book is practically over, and only in a much deficient form. Where are those damn Voronoi diagrams? Rating: 2.5 stars

If you have a strong enough stomach to tolerate graphic descriptions of the state of sanitation in Victorian London, and you have an interest in epidemiology, this book is for you. It's fascinating! More like a 3.5. I greatly enjoyed this, though I can see the subject matter would be potentially super dry for some. I recently finished this book and was very pleasantly surprised to discover that it had a great deal to teach me about a subject that I thought I knew well. It turned out that I knew the legend rather than the facts. This book is certainly packed with facts; however they are presented in such a clear attractive fashion,that it reads as easily as fiction. I heartily recommend this book. It is not just a book about an epidemic. It has a great deal to say about cities as machines for sustaining commerce, culture, employment and leisure. This is a really good account of the outbreak of cholera that led to John Snow’s famous map, showing that a particular water pump was the culprit. He traces the history of how London dealt with sewage and how it became such a big issue, and also examines some of the main characters in the drama of trying to stop the outbreak — and trying to challenge miasma theory, which was so much the paradigm at the time. There isn’t a lot of specific science stuff here, but Johnson makes clear why the cholera pathogen is so deadly in a very accessible way.The only weird part is in the conclusion/afterword to the book, where Johnson talks more generally about the risks to city life and starts discussing nuclear war and terrorism. It seems very much a non-sequitur, and adds nothing to the book to my mind.Reviewed for The Bibliophibian.

Disappointing pop science. I learned about Snow's mapping of London's cholera epidemic in my graduate stats class and hoped this book would delve deeper into the process of its creation and lasting impact on public health and statistics (and help in my quest to better understand math and science, after brushing both (especially the latter) aside in favor of the humanities and social sciences). Unfortunately, the book dragged out over 200-plus pages the initial article I had read in class. It was notable that the tale focused on not only the celebrated Snow, but the until recently obscured local pastor, Whitehead, who really did the fieldwork that backed up Snow's waterborne theory. Only recommended to those who've never encountered this story in another format (and who won't wince at detailed descriptions of cholera symptoms).

A fascinating and gripping tale of science - and more interestingly how science overcomes faith in false ideas that actually are causing harm -- the idea of miasma causing illness. (Global warming hysteria comes to my mind, but certainly not the author's.) Unfortunately, the author completely drops the ball with the ending. The book suddenly turns to molasses, and it appears he didn't know how to end it. After reading the end notes, I got the impression that he grafted his undergraduate thesis into the ending. He also goes off on some wild tangents (nuclear weapons elimination!) at the very end in essentially a double-I-just-can't-end the book ending. Could have been 4 or 5 stars if he had kept up the pace he started with, but bizarrely it just crumbles at the end.

The fascinating story of the beginnings of the science of epidemiology. When a cholera outbreak strikes a London neighborhood in 1854, Dr. John Snow sets out to gather proof for his theory that the disease is caused by drinking contaminated water, and not by miasma (foul air), which was the popular theory of the time. He famously drew a map showing the location of the victims and the locations of the neighborhood water pumps.The subject is very interesting and the book is well written, but the author meanders quite a bit and is repetitive at times. Towards the end he branches out to discuss the benefits and risks of urban density.

This book is hard to rate. I enjoyed the details about the cholera epidemic and felt like Johnson's narrative style made it much more interesting than it actually was (or than the available evidence allows). But the changing of science/cities/the modern world? Nope. Getting kind of sick of these pseudo-historians trying to be all "X made the whole world different." Also there were a lot of weirdly privileged arguments...e.g. "poor people and rich people live in cities for exactly the same reason...because that's where the action is." Nope. And there was also a racist passage about Native Americans that didn't sit right.

London was the largest city in the world in the 1850s. It had no functional sewage system. This book paints a vivid picture of the sanitary conditions of the time, and gives an overview of the awful impact of cholera, a disease that (we now know) is typically transmitted in contaminated water. Talk about a timely read. This is something I picked up used before the current disaster, and I remember thinking it was of some interest but more of as an historical artifact. The book deals in some detail, although not overwhelming, with an 1854 cholera outbreak in London and the efforts to figure out what caused it. Cholera of course was well known in that era around the world and caused numerous epidemics, including as recently as 2016-2020 in Yemen. But the prevailing belief (quasi-scientific) in the 1850s and before was that it was caused by 'miasma', i.e. bad air. That notion was hard to shake amongst the cognoscenti of the time. But Dr. John Snow, a name I had not heard before, came up with the theory on the waterborne nature of cholera. He did not even know what in the water would have caused it, turned out to be a bacterium called vibrio cholerae (which actually had been identified by an Italian anatomist around the same time, but that was unknown to Snow). Of course, he was ridiculed despite already being a highly respected physician who was a pioneer in the use of anesthesia. His intense research and close partnership with Rev. Henry Whitehead on the sociological aspects of the epidemic were ground-breaking for the time. And his map of the outbreak (hence the name of book) which he used to illustrate the relationship between contaminated water sources and fatalities became dare I say, a watershed in the use of cartography for epidemiological analysis. From this to the Johns Hopkins site being used for Covid-19. The book written in 2006 is also a paean to the virtues of city living. The solution of the cholera mystery made modern large cities possible, today on a scale unimaginable in the 1850s. And parts of the book are almost an urban worship-fest. Only cities can save us from ourselves, he opines. But in his final chapters on coming epidemics and pandemics he clearly recognizes the threat that has arrived on our doorsteps today. He discusses H5N1 ('bird flu') and the threat it posed back in 2006 but noted the lack of easy transmission from human to human. Well, obviously COVID-19 ('bat flu' or 'lab flu'?) does not follow those ancient rules and suddenly cities look vulnerable again.

The Ghost Map tells the story of how Dr John Snow, a London physician, solved the problem of how to tackle Cholera. Johnson starts his historical tale by setting the scene and in particular detailing the filth and stench of the city and the various professions who cleaned and recycled the city’s waste. In the absence of sewers and formalized waste management, human and animal faeces littered streets and basements. It was the foul-smelling stench – the miasma – of such waste that was thought to spread disease. Snow, however, had a different theory – disease was spread via contaminated water – and most of the book concerns Snow’s work. In particular, the narrative focuses on the 1854 cholera epidemic, its catastrophic outcome on a local community, how by plotting ghosts on a map Snow identified the source of the outbreak, changing both the practice of epidemiology and public infrastructure and public health provision of modern cities globally. It’s an interesting tale, but it is a little uneven in its telling, with an overextended focus on some elements that drifted into repetition, and underdeveloped on others, particularly the public health situation and response, and the evolution of thinking and practice in the years proceeding Snow’s work. And the final chapter on the spread of disease and viruses in the present day, as well as urban development, was a potted attempt to convert the lesson from the nineteenth century to the present that felt like an add-on and speculative. In addition, the lack of Snow’s maps and analysis, especially the key Voronoi one, seemed an important oversight. Overall, an okay read about an interesting case.

It’s the mid-19th century and London is a city. Almost miraculously, a group of people have organised themselves into a class of scavengers, taking on the responsibility of most modern sanitation departments and thus helping two million people get rid of their waste. However, this effort does have some cracks and not all waste is gotten rid of. One particular household’s waste, in particular, is thrown out and lands near a certain pump.The Ghost Map is an account of the John Snow and to a lesser extent, Henry Whitehead’s investigations into a series of chlorea cases (the 1854 Broad Street Chlorea Outbreak) that led to the discovery of a contaminated pump and the dismantling of the miasma theory.Told in seven chapters, each one representing a day, The Ghost Map presents a detailed and sometimes wandering account of how John Snow conducted his investigations. Through this account, the book manages to give the reader a general introduction to who John Snow is, including his work with anaesthesia, as well as why the discovery of water contamination and its relationship to cholera was so important for cities to continue growing without large numbers of deaths.To be honest, the book felt rather longwinded in parts, especially since it has the tendency to digress to other topics (about miasma theory, especially). But I generally enjoyed reading this book. It was heavy, particularly in the current climate, but I think the fact that the cause of transmission of the cholera outbreak could be discovered and stopped gives hope that we can stop future outbreaks of diseases if we approach the situation with an open mind.Overall, I enjoyed it. It’s not the most gripping nonfiction history book that I’ve read but history buffs may be interested in exploring this aspect of medical history.This review was first posted at Eustea Reads

Mind blown! The story took a bit to get going and there are definitely some dry parts. But wow was it packed with fascinating information. We can now look down our noses at the ignorance of our forefathers trying to cure illness and disease with poultices and castor oil and smoke. But what will our great great great grandchildren say about our “advanced medical knowledge” today? We do the best we can with what we’ve got, just like every human civilization has done. My ah-ha moment was right near the middle. Of course we now know that cholera was spread by London’s water supply in 1853. But they didn’t then. And many people tried to figure it out with logic and experiment. A lot of amazing scientific hero’s stayed in London’s Broad Street even though staying might mean certain death. Many people in that time drank water. But things were changing. Many of our forefathers survived because they chose alcohol over water. It was better to die from cirrhosis of the liver at 40 than microbial diseases at 20. In order to tolerate alcohol our bodies need to produce the enzymes alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH) and aldehyde dehydrogenase (ALDH) from chromosome 4. Not everyone has the genetics to digest alcohol. And many years ago, fewer people could do this. With humans moving from rural to urban centres we created some waste related issues for ourselves. The more concentrated the human population, the dirtier our water supplies became, the greater chance of water born diseases. Hence people that could digest alcohol had a higher probability of living through microbial disease and procreate. Whereas the ones that couldn’t digest alcohol, stuck with water and didn’t live long enough to procreate. This in turn bottlenecked our Caucasian genetics to be able to tolerate alcohol easily. And here was my ah-ha moment. A historical culture that didn’t urbanize and bottleneck their genetics was the indigenous cultures of Australia and North America. These cultures are well known in today’s culture for their issues with alcohol. And Johnson theorizes that their rural hunting and gathering not only preventing them from developing immunity to many urban diseases but may have contributed to their genetic issues with alcohol. A very thought provoking theory. I really enjoyed the journey Snow and Whitehead went through to figure out the problem of cholera. It was also interesting to see the coincidences that prevented cholera from doing even more damage.I’m sure this book isn’t for everyone. But I thoroughly enjoyed it!
