But stick with it, the fun science starts a few chapters in.At the time, everyone thought diseases were caused by "miasmas" which as the author explains was kind of understandable because cities smelled terrible at the time, and we are naturally inclined to feel sick when we smell poop, decay, etc. People also did not fully understand the difference between a virus, which can be spread by airborne methods, and a bacterial infection, which generally can not.Dr John Snow therefore had to work overtime to build a procedural case for cholera being a waterborne disease to present to authorities. He did it through a combination of scientific observation and sociological study, using a now-famous map to trace the spread of the disease. In the end, the handle was removed from the famous Broad Street pump which had been the vector for the particularly virulent strain of cholera that wiped out much of Soho. His evidence contributed to the development of the London sewer system, a massive engineering project that was way ahead of its time, and set the pattern for modern urban sanitation systems. The book finishes up with a discussion of how these systems basically make civilization sustainable on the planet because dense cities are the most efficient and sustainable way for people to live (if they have proper plumbing, clearly!)So, now I guess I'm going to have find a book about the guy who built the London sewers!

Mind blown! The story took a bit to get going and there are definitely some dry parts. But wow was it packed with fascinating information. We can now look down our noses at the ignorance of our forefathers trying to cure illness and disease with poultices and castor oil and smoke. But what will our great great great grandchildren say about our “advanced medical knowledge” today? We do the best we can with what we’ve got, just like every human civilization has done. My ah-ha moment was right near the middle. Of course we now know that cholera was spread by London’s water supply in 1853. But they didn’t then. And many people tried to figure it out with logic and experiment. A lot of amazing scientific hero’s stayed in London’s Broad Street even though staying might mean certain death. Many people in that time drank water. But things were changing. Many of our forefathers survived because they chose alcohol over water. It was better to die from cirrhosis of the liver at 40 than microbial diseases at 20. In order to tolerate alcohol our bodies need to produce the enzymes alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH) and aldehyde dehydrogenase (ALDH) from chromosome 4. Not everyone has the genetics to digest alcohol. And many years ago, fewer people could do this. With humans moving from rural to urban centres we created some waste related issues for ourselves. The more concentrated the human population, the dirtier our water supplies became, the greater chance of water born diseases. Hence people that could digest alcohol had a higher probability of living through microbial disease and procreate. Whereas the ones that couldn’t digest alcohol, stuck with water and didn’t live long enough to procreate. This in turn bottlenecked our Caucasian genetics to be able to tolerate alcohol easily. And here was my ah-ha moment. A historical culture that didn’t urbanize and bottleneck their genetics was the indigenous cultures of Australia and North America. These cultures are well known in today’s culture for their issues with alcohol. And Johnson theorizes that their rural hunting and gathering not only preventing them from developing immunity to many urban diseases but may have contributed to their genetic issues with alcohol. A very thought provoking theory. I really enjoyed the journey Snow and Whitehead went through to figure out the problem of cholera. It was also interesting to see the coincidences that prevented cholera from doing even more damage.I’m sure this book isn’t for everyone. But I thoroughly enjoyed it!

If you have a strong enough stomach to tolerate graphic descriptions of the state of sanitation in Victorian London, and you have an interest in epidemiology, this book is for you. It's fascinating! I will never look at a glass of water the same way again! Some other reviewers comment that this book meanders away from the main narrative describing the outbreak of cholera in London in 1854. The book talks about the detective work of Dr. John Snow who ultimately traced the outbreak to a local water supply using careful data collection and rudimentary disease mapping to advance his unpopular theory on the spread of the disease which went against the existing, accepted medical paradigm. Perhaps, because I listened to the audiobook, the meandering philosophical discussion of the implications of the case did not bog me down as it would have if I was reading. Instead, it seemed like reasonable elaboration on a topic with far-reaching relevance, especially to topics such as population growth, urbanization, public health,epidemiology and statistics in medicine.

More like a 3.5. I greatly enjoyed this, though I can see the subject matter would be potentially super dry for some. I find the practicalities of 19th Century urbanisation amid the Industrial Revolution very interesting, particularly in London. Gives extra depth to anyone who spends time reading Dickens or other fiction taking place at that time. Also anyone interested in GIS applications for medical information, how maps and topography are used to track epidemics, would find these early days super interesting. In the last chapter he touches on the way technology has changed the scale of disease tracking now that we have Google maps and geotagging, etc.Overall an interesting slice of history. And because they spent so much time talking about Soho and street names and maps, I looked up Snow's Cholera map to compare it with a modern map on Google well before I go to the end of the book. Putting street view onto the corner where the pump was located was a neat surprise, to see the name of the pub there.

This was an AMAZING novel!!!!! If you like science, this book is just right for you! It all started with one microorganism...It was capable to kill thousands of people. Learn about London’s most dreadful epidemic. It made me feel so nervous and suspicious, because of that mysterious origin of the bacteria… This novel truly uncovered for me the importance of interdependece and the life order the earth depends on. This novel uncovered for me that competition in scientific world can help and motivate people greatly. Three different scientists using such various methods to trace the virus led them to unite at one point their discoveries for one final step: discovering the origin causing such dreadful consequences. ONCE PASSION AND MOTIVATION UNITE THE CREATION OF RESOLUTION IS NEAR..... Read this novel to find out if the timing was just right, if the epidemic spread was fatal or stopped.....

I recently finished this book and was very pleasantly surprised to discover that it had a great deal to teach me about a subject that I thought I knew well. It turned out that I knew the legend rather than the facts. This book is certainly packed with facts; however they are presented in such a clear attractive fashion,that it reads as easily as fiction. I heartily recommend this book. It is not just a book about an epidemic. It has a great deal to say about cities as machines for sustaining commerce, culture, employment and leisure. The Victorians had developed the machine, but lacked a trouble shooter's manual. They faced a deadly glitch in the form of a cholera epidemic in the time before antibiotics, public sanitation departments or even the knowledge of the germ method of contagion. It caused me to reflect on the complexity and vulnerability of our modern metropolises and to wonder where the next glitch may appear.

This is a really good account of the outbreak of cholera that led to John Snow’s famous map, showing that a particular water pump was the culprit. He traces the history of how London dealt with sewage and how it became such a big issue, and also examines some of the main characters in the drama of trying to stop the outbreak — and trying to challenge miasma theory, which was so much the paradigm at the time. There isn’t a lot of specific science stuff here, but Johnson makes clear why the cholera pathogen is so deadly in a very accessible way.The only weird part is in the conclusion/afterword to the book, where Johnson talks more generally about the risks to city life and starts discussing nuclear war and terrorism. It seems very much a non-sequitur, and adds nothing to the book to my mind.Reviewed for The Bibliophibian.

Disappointing pop science. I learned about Snow's mapping of London's cholera epidemic in my graduate stats class and hoped this book would delve deeper into the process of its creation and lasting impact on public health and statistics (and help in my quest to better understand math and science, after brushing both (especially the latter) aside in favor of the humanities and social sciences). Unfortunately, the book dragged out over 200-plus pages the initial article I had read in class. It was notable that the tale focused on not only the celebrated Snow, but the until recently obscured local pastor, Whitehead, who really did the fieldwork that backed up Snow's waterborne theory. Only recommended to those who've never encountered this story in another format (and who won't wince at detailed descriptions of cholera symptoms).

A fascinating and gripping tale of science - and more interestingly how science overcomes faith in false ideas that actually are causing harm -- the idea of miasma causing illness. (Global warming hysteria comes to my mind, but certainly not the author's.) Unfortunately, the author completely drops the ball with the ending. The book suddenly turns to molasses, and it appears he didn't know how to end it. After reading the end notes, I got the impression that he grafted his undergraduate thesis into the ending. He also goes off on some wild tangents (nuclear weapons elimination!) at the very end in essentially a double-I-just-can't-end the book ending. Could have been 4 or 5 stars if he had kept up the pace he started with, but bizarrely it just crumbles at the end.

The fascinating story of the beginnings of the science of epidemiology. When a cholera outbreak strikes a London neighborhood in 1854, Dr. John Snow sets out to gather proof for his theory that the disease is caused by drinking contaminated water, and not by miasma (foul air), which was the popular theory of the time. He famously drew a map showing the location of the victims and the locations of the neighborhood water pumps.The subject is very interesting and the book is well written, but the author meanders quite a bit and is repetitive at times. Towards the end he branches out to discuss the benefits and risks of urban density.

This book is hard to rate. I enjoyed the details about the cholera epidemic and felt like Johnson's narrative style made it much more interesting than it actually was (or than the available evidence allows). But the changing of science/cities/the modern world? Nope. Getting kind of sick of these pseudo-historians trying to be all "X made the whole world different." Also there were a lot of weirdly privileged arguments...e.g. "poor people and rich people live in cities for exactly the same reason...because that's where the action is." Nope. And there was also a racist passage about Native Americans that didn't sit right.

London was the largest city in the world in the 1850s. It had no functional sewage system. This book paints a vivid picture of the sanitary conditions of the time, and gives an overview of the awful impact of cholera, a disease that (we now know) is typically transmitted in contaminated water. When a massive cholera epidemic hit London in 1854, a group of researchers tried to understand what caused the disease and how to stop it.This was a very interesting study of the deductive and inductive processes that led to the new understanding of the critical importance of better sanitation.

A very interesting novel, this work presents its subject matter in a unique way. I thoroughly enjoyed the style with which Steven Johnson tells a story while also demonstrating the scientific and demographic considerations. He incorporates politics, microbiology, and cartography into a good novel, and though he switches points of view and tenses often amid different chapters, he maintains the readers' interests while educating. A solid read.

I read that at least one US university selected The Ghost Map as its 2015 common freshman reading, which prompted me to pick it up for a reread. It's an excellent choice. Johnson models interdisciplinary inquiry as he tells the story of such an enquirer, and the writing is accessible and vivid. I feel odd saying that I 'enjoyed' a book that includes so much discussion of sewage, but nevertheless there it is.

Really a 3.5 star for me. 3/4 of the book was 5 stars but it's all pretty boring and downhill after the mystery is solved. Especially when the author starts referencing The Population Bomb as anything other than BS. In hindsight I would have stopped when he got to talking about the map. BUT the majority of this book is completely fascinating and I'm now obsessed with cholera, 19th century London and sewage systems, and those are words I never thought I'd write.

I have some mixed feelings on this book in the end. Mostly this comes from the last 50 pages or so where the author relates the cholera outbreak and city growth and development to our modern age. It gave me plenty to think about and a good reading list for the future. I was disappointed that he propagated the myth of the Chicag0 1885 cholera epidemic. That's easy research that should have been done.

I knew next to nothing about the 1854 cholera epidemic before picking this book. Now I feel like an expert on the event and the sewer systems. I think my favorite part was the acknowledgement that engineering had as much to do with solving the problem as medicine. My least favorite thing was the epilogue that felt oddly out of place after almost 300 pages of cholera discussion.**I received a copy of this book in exchange for an honest review.**

A facinating medical detective story about the uncovering of the real cause of the horrific cholera outbreak in a Victorian London neighborhood. The author brings the era and its environmental problems to life as he honors the analytical genius of the two main protagonists. A page turner that carries one into another time and place. Public Health history at its best.

In some ways, it felt like it was two books sandwiched together, and I much preferred the narrative part to the areas where Johnson editorializes, even if I do mostly agree with his positions. It was not easy reading -- I definitely didn't race through it -- but worth the effort, I think. I learned a lot of both science and history.

I greatly enjoyed reading this book. I struggle getting through nonfiction, and I wound up having to listen to this book instead of reading it, but despite my hiatus this book has become one of my favorites. I didnt like how it became pro urbanization propaganda, but it did make sense so I guess I cant be too upset about it...

I love the story of Dr. John Snow, the first epidemiologist. I did not like how the book ends with the author arguing points regarding the story's implications to the modern era. I wished the author would have stopped with the well-told story.

Although I really did enjoy this, I wasn't expecting the two hour lecture at the end. It was good and informative and I enjoyed it, but it wasn't really something I needed sprung on me. I docked a star for it.

The subject of this book, is right up my alley. I work in a hospital lab and am fascinated by epidemiology. While I knew a little of John Snow and the London Cholera outbreak, this story went so much more in depth than anything else I've read.

Who would have thought that a book about cholera could be so fascinating? The lively style of writing made this book accessible and entertaining as well as informative. Definitely an author from whom I will now read more.
The best book about poop I've read so far!I should have skipped the epilogue with the babbling about nuclear war, terrorism, and peak energy. It was a horrible ending to an otherwise great book.
I'm kind of annoyed that this was pretty great and then fell apart in the last 2 hours when the author decided they had to make it "relevant" to today's increasing urbanization. :-///

Talk about a timely read. This is something I picked up used before the current disaster, and I remember thinking it was of some interest but more of as an historical artifact. The book deals in some detail, although not overwhelming, with an 1854 cholera outbreak in London and the efforts to figure out what caused it. Cholera of course was well known in that era around the world and caused numerous epidemics, including as recently as 2016-2020 in Yemen. But the prevailing belief (quasi-scientific) in the 1850s and before was that it was caused by 'miasma', i.e. bad air. That notion was hard to shake amongst the cognoscenti of the time. But Dr. John Snow, a name I had not heard before, came up with the theory on the waterborne nature of cholera. He did not even know what in the water would have caused it, turned out to be a bacterium called vibrio cholerae (which actually had been identified by an Italian anatomist around the same time, but that was unknown to Snow). Of course, he was ridiculed despite already being a highly respected physician who was a pioneer in the use of anesthesia. His intense research and close partnership with Rev. Henry Whitehead on the sociological aspects of the epidemic were ground-breaking for the time. And his map of the outbreak (hence the name of book) which he used to illustrate the relationship between contaminated water sources and fatalities became dare I say, a watershed in the use of cartography for epidemiological analysis. From this to the Johns Hopkins site being used for Covid-19. The book written in 2006 is also a paean to the virtues of city living. The solution of the cholera mystery made modern large cities possible, today on a scale unimaginable in the 1850s. And parts of the book are almost an urban worship-fest. Only cities can save us from ourselves, he opines. But in his final chapters on coming epidemics and pandemics he clearly recognizes the threat that has arrived on our doorsteps today. He discusses H5N1 ('bird flu') and the threat it posed back in 2006 but noted the lack of easy transmission from human to human. Well, obviously COVID-19 ('bat flu' or 'lab flu'?) does not follow those ancient rules and suddenly cities look vulnerable again.

The Ghost Map tells the story of how Dr John Snow, a London physician, solved the problem of how to tackle Cholera. Johnson starts his historical tale by setting the scene and in particular detailing the filth and stench of the city and the various professions who cleaned and recycled the city’s waste. In the absence of sewers and formalized waste management, human and animal faeces littered streets and basements. It was the foul-smelling stench – the miasma – of such waste that was thought to spread disease. Snow, however, had a different theory – disease was spread via contaminated water – and most of the book concerns Snow’s work. In particular, the narrative focuses on the 1854 cholera epidemic, its catastrophic outcome on a local community, how by plotting ghosts on a map Snow identified the source of the outbreak, changing both the practice of epidemiology and public infrastructure and public health provision of modern cities globally. It’s an interesting tale, but it is a little uneven in its telling, with an overextended focus on some elements that drifted into repetition, and underdeveloped on others, particularly the public health situation and response, and the evolution of thinking and practice in the years proceeding Snow’s work. And the final chapter on the spread of disease and viruses in the present day, as well as urban development, was a potted attempt to convert the lesson from the nineteenth century to the present that felt like an add-on and speculative. In addition, the lack of Snow’s maps and analysis, especially the key Voronoi one, seemed an important oversight. Overall, an okay read about an interesting case.

It’s the mid-19th century and London is a city. Almost miraculously, a group of people have organised themselves into a class of scavengers, taking on the responsibility of most modern sanitation departments and thus helping two million people get rid of their waste. However, this effort does have some cracks and not all waste is gotten rid of. One particular household’s waste, in particular, is thrown out and lands near a certain pump.The Ghost Map is an account of the John Snow and to a lesser extent, Henry Whitehead’s investigations into a series of chlorea cases (the 1854 Broad Street Chlorea Outbreak) that led to the discovery of a contaminated pump and the dismantling of the miasma theory.Told in seven chapters, each one representing a day, The Ghost Map presents a detailed and sometimes wandering account of how John Snow conducted his investigations. Through this account, the book manages to give the reader a general introduction to who John Snow is, including his work with anaesthesia, as well as why the discovery of water contamination and its relationship to cholera was so important for cities to continue growing without large numbers of deaths.To be honest, the book felt rather longwinded in parts, especially since it has the tendency to digress to other topics (about miasma theory, especially). But I generally enjoyed reading this book. It was heavy, particularly in the current climate, but I think the fact that the cause of transmission of the cholera outbreak could be discovered and stopped gives hope that we can stop future outbreaks of diseases if we approach the situation with an open mind.Overall, I enjoyed it. It’s not the most gripping nonfiction history book that I’ve read but history buffs may be interested in exploring this aspect of medical history.This review was first posted at Eustea Reads

3.25 stars. My high school friend lent me this book almost a decade ago and I just didn't read it because it intimidated me. But I'm STRONGER now and I finally read it! 💪I am very glad I read this as an audiobook because it would've been much harder for me to get through otherwise. I'm personally drawn to many things at once and would have probably put this down in favor of something else because it's dense with information and while well-researched and interesting, it's not exactly so riveting, I'd drop everything else. But I wanted to read this now and understand how it might relate to what's happening in the world today, especially in high-population cities.I didn't understand why so many "experts" at the time didn't take to theories of mass infection by ingesting water from the same location rather than "because it smells so bad." 😒 I do, however, know that what we consider common sense today was built by people who had to sway public opinions with what, at the time, was groundbreaking leaps in logic. "The virus that causes such international panic does not exist yet" 👀"Some experts think a pandemic on the order of 1918 is a near inevitability" 👀👀"But we'll have the tools at our disposal to deal with the emerging threats if we're smart enough to deploy them." 👀👀👀👀👀👀👀It's a whole different animal to have a virus passed from human to human so easily and carelessly compared to diseases that arose from poor living conditions and a lack of sanitary resources. Both nightmares, both harbingers of mass death, both serving as catalysts for advancement in vaccine medicine and genetic composition analysis.

But Dr. John Snow, a name I had not heard before, came up with the theory on the waterborne nature of cholera. He did not even know what in the water would have caused it, turned out to be a bacterium called vibrio cholerae (which actually had been identified by an Italian anatomist around the same time, but that was unknown to Snow). Of course, he was ridiculed despite already being a highly respected physician who was a pioneer in the use of anesthesia. His intense research and close partnership with Rev. Henry Whitehead on the sociological aspects of the epidemic were ground-breaking for the time. And his map of the outbreak (hence the name of book) which he used to illustrate the relationship between contaminated water sources and fatalities became dare I say, a watershed in the use of cartography for epidemiological analysis. From this to the Johns Hopkins site being used for Covid-19. The book written in 2006 is also a paean to the virtues of city living. The solution of the cholera mystery made modern large cities possible, today on a scale unimaginable in the 1850s. And parts of the book are almost an urban worship-fest. Only cities can save us from ourselves, he opines. But in his final chapters on coming epidemics and pandemics he clearly recognizes the threat that has arrived on our doorsteps today. He discusses H5N1 ('bird flu') and the threat it posed back in 2006 but noted the lack of easy transmission from human to human. Well, obviously COVID-19 ('bat flu' or 'lab flu'?) does not follow those ancient rules and suddenly cities look vulnerable again.

The Ghost Map tells the story of how Dr John Snow, a London physician, solved the problem of how to tackle Cholera. Johnson starts his historical tale by setting the scene and in particular detailing the filth and stench of the city and the various professions who cleaned and recycled the city’s waste. In the absence of sewers and formalized waste management, human and animal faeces littered streets and basements. It was the foul-smelling stench – the miasma – of such waste that was thought to spread disease. Snow, however, had a different theory – disease was spread via contaminated water – and most of the book concerns Snow’s work. In particular, the narrative focuses on the 1854 cholera epidemic, its catastrophic outcome on a local community, how by plotting ghosts on a map Snow identified the source of the outbreak, changing both the practice of epidemiology and public infrastructure and public health provision of modern cities globally. It’s an interesting tale, but it is a little uneven in its telling, with an overextended focus on some elements that drifted into repetition, and underdeveloped on others, particularly the public health situation and response, and the evolution of thinking and practice in the years proceeding Snow’s work. And the final chapter on the spread of disease and viruses in the present day, as well as urban development, was a potted attempt to convert the lesson from the nineteenth century to the present that felt like an add-on and speculative. In addition, the lack of Snow’s maps and analysis, especially the key Voronoi one, seemed an important oversight. Overall, an okay read about an interesting case.

It’s the mid-19th century and London is a city. However, this effort does have some cracks and not all waste is gotten rid of. One particular household’s waste, in particular, is thrown out and lands near a certain pump.The Ghost Map is an account of the John Snow and to a lesser extent, Henry Whitehead’s investigations into a series of chlorea cases (the 1854 Broad Street Chlorea Outbreak) that led to the discovery of a contaminated pump and the dismantling of the miasma theory.Told in seven chapters, each one representing a day, The Ghost Map presents a detailed and sometimes wandering account of how John Snow conducted his investigations. Through this account, the book manages to give the reader a general introduction to who John Snow is, including his work with anaesthesia, as well as why the discovery of water contamination and its relationship to cholera was so important for cities to continue growing without large numbers of deaths.To be honest, the book felt rather longwinded in parts, especially since it has the tendency to digress to other topics (about miasma theory, especially). But I generally enjoyed reading this book. It was heavy, particularly in the current climate, but I think the fact that the cause of transmission of the cholera outbreak could be discovered and stopped gives hope that we can stop future outbreaks of diseases if we approach the situation with an open mind.Overall, I enjoyed it. It’s not the most gripping nonfiction history book that I’ve read but history buffs may be interested in exploring this aspect of medical history.This review was first posted at Eustea Reads

Many people in that time drank water. But things were changing. Many of our forefathers survived because they chose alcohol over water. It was better to die from cirrhosis of the liver at 40 than microbial diseases at 20. In order to tolerate alcohol our bodies need to produce the enzymes alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH) and aldehyde dehydrogenase (ALDH) from chromosome 4. Not everyone has the genetics to digest alcohol. The more concentrated the human population, the dirtier our water supplies became, the greater chance of water born diseases. Hence people that could digest alcohol had a higher probability of living through microbial disease and procreate. But stick with it, the fun science starts a few chapters in.At the time, everyone thought diseases were caused by "miasmas" which as the author explains was kind of understandable because cities smelled terrible at the time, and we are naturally inclined to feel sick when we smell poop, decay, etc. People also did not fully understand the difference between a virus, which can be spread by airborne methods, and a bacterial infection, which generally can not.Dr John Snow therefore had to work overtime to build a procedural case for cholera being a waterborne disease to present to authorities. He did it through a combination of scientific observation and sociological study, using a now-famous map to trace the spread of the disease. In the end, the handle was removed from the famous Broad Street pump which had been the vector for the particularly virulent strain of cholera that wiped out much of Soho. His evidence contributed to the development of the London sewer system, a massive engineering project that was way ahead of its time, and set the pattern for modern urban sanitation systems. The book finishes up with a discussion of how these systems basically make civilization sustainable on the planet because dense cities are the most efficient and sustainable way for people to live (if they have proper plumbing, clearly!)So, now I guess I'm going to have find a book about the guy who built the London sewers!

Mind blown! The story took a bit to get going and there are definitely some dry parts. But wow was it packed with fascinating information. We can now look down our noses at the ignorance of our forefathers trying to cure illness and disease with poultices and castor oil and smoke. But what will our great great great grandchildren say about our “advanced medical knowledge” today? We do the best we can with what we’ve got, just like every human civilization has done. My ah-ha moment was right near the middle. Of course we now know that cholera was spread by London’s water supply in 1853. But they didn’t then. And many people tried to figure it out with logic and experiment. A lot of amazing scientific hero’s stayed in London’s Broad Street even though staying might mean certain death. Many people in that time drank water. But things were changing. Many of our forefathers survived because they chose alcohol over water. It was better to die from cirrhosis of the liver at 40 than microbial diseases at 20. In order to tolerate alcohol our bodies need to produce the enzymes alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH) and aldehyde dehydrogenase (ALDH) from chromosome 4. Not everyone has the genetics to digest alcohol. And many years ago, fewer people could do this. With humans moving from rural to urban centres we created some waste related issues for ourselves. The more concentrated the human population, the dirtier our water supplies became, the greater chance of water born diseases. Hence people that could digest alcohol had a higher probability of living through microbial disease and procreate. Whereas the ones that couldn’t digest alcohol, stuck with water and didn’t live long enough to procreate. This in turn bottlenecked our Caucasian genetics to be able to tolerate alcohol easily. And here was my ah-ha moment. A historical culture that didn’t urbanize and bottleneck their genetics was the indigenous cultures of Australia and North America. These cultures are well known in today’s culture for their issues with alcohol. And Johnson theorizes that their rural hunting and gathering not only preventing them from developing immunity to many urban diseases but may have contributed to their genetic issues with alcohol. A very thought provoking theory. I really enjoyed the journey Snow and Whitehead went through to figure out the problem of cholera. It was also interesting to see the coincidences that prevented cholera from doing even more damage.I’m sure this book isn’t for everyone. But I thoroughly enjoyed it!

If you have a strong enough stomach to tolerate graphic descriptions of the state of sanitation in Victorian London, and you have an interest in epidemiology, this book is for you. It's fascinating! I will never look at a glass of water the same way again! Some other reviewers comment that this book meanders away from the main narrative describing the outbreak of cholera in London in 1854. The book talks about the detective work of Dr. John Snow who ultimately traced the outbreak to a local water supply using careful data collection and rudimentary disease mapping to advance his unpopular theory on the spread of the disease which went against the existing, accepted medical paradigm. Perhaps, because I listened to the audiobook, the meandering philosophical discussion of the implications of the case did not bog me down as it would have if I was reading. Instead, it seemed like reasonable elaboration on a topic with far-reaching relevance, especially to topics such as population growth, urbanization, public health,epidemiology and statistics in medicine.

More like a 3.5. I greatly enjoyed this, though I can see the subject matter would be potentially super dry for some. I find the practicalities of 19th Century urbanisation amid the Industrial Revolution very interesting, particularly in London. Gives extra depth to anyone who spends time reading Dickens or other fiction taking place at that time. Also anyone interested in GIS applications for medical information, how maps and topography are used to track epidemics, would find these early days super interesting. In the last chapter he touches on the way technology has changed the scale of disease tracking now that we have Google maps and geotagging, etc.Overall an interesting slice of history. And because they spent so much time talking about Soho and street names and maps, I looked up Snow's Cholera map to compare it with a modern map on Google well before I go to the end of the book. Putting street view onto the corner where the pump was located was a neat surprise, to see the name of the pub there.

This was an AMAZING novel!!!!! If you like science, this book is just right for you! It all started with one microorganism...It was capable to kill thousands of people. Learn about London’s most dreadful epidemic. It made me feel so nervous and suspicious, because of that mysterious origin of the bacteria… This novel truly uncovered for me the importance of interdependece and the life order the earth depends on. This novel uncovered for me that competition in scientific world can help and motivate people greatly. Three different scientists using such various methods to trace the virus led them to unite at one point their discoveries for one final step: discovering the origin causing such dreadful consequences. ONCE PASSION AND MOTIVATION UNITE THE CREATION OF RESOLUTION IS NEAR..... Read this novel to find out if the timing was just right, if the epidemic spread was fatal or stopped.....

I recently finished this book and was very pleasantly surprised to discover that it had a great deal to teach me about a subject that I thought I knew well. It turned out that I knew the legend rather than the facts. This book is certainly packed with facts; however they are presented in such a clear attractive fashion,that it reads as easily as fiction. I heartily recommend this book. It is not just a book about an epidemic. It has a great deal to say about cities as machines for sustaining commerce, culture, employment and leisure. The Victorians had developed the machine, but lacked a trouble shooter's manual. They faced a deadly glitch in the form of a cholera epidemic in the time before antibiotics, public sanitation departments or even the knowledge of the germ method of contagion. It caused me to reflect on the complexity and vulnerability of our modern metropolises and to wonder where the next glitch may appear.

This is a really good account of the outbreak of cholera that led to John Snow’s famous map, showing that a particular water pump was the culprit. He traces the history of how London dealt with sewage and how it became such a big issue, and also examines some of the main characters in the drama of trying to stop the outbreak — and trying to challenge miasma theory, which was so much the paradigm at the time. There isn’t a lot of specific science stuff here, but Johnson makes clear why the cholera pathogen is so deadly in a very accessible way.The only weird part is in the conclusion/afterword to the book, where Johnson talks more generally about the risks to city life and starts discussing nuclear war and terrorism. It seems very much a non-sequitur, and adds nothing to the book to my mind.Reviewed for The Bibliophibian.

Disappointing pop science. I learned about Snow's mapping of London's cholera epidemic in my graduate stats class and hoped this book would delve deeper into the process of its creation and lasting impact on public health and statistics (and help in my quest to better understand math and science, after brushing both (especially the latter) aside in favor of the humanities and social sciences). Unfortunately, the book dragged out over 200-plus pages the initial article I had read in class. It was notable that the tale focused on not only the celebrated Snow, but the until recently obscured local pastor, Whitehead, who really did the fieldwork that backed up Snow's waterborne theory. Only recommended to those who've never encountered this story in another format (and who won't wince at detailed descriptions of cholera symptoms).

A fascinating and gripping tale of science - and more interestingly how science overcomes faith in false ideas that actually are causing harm -- the idea of miasma causing illness. (Global warming hysteria comes to my mind, but certainly not the author's.) Unfortunately, the author completely drops the ball with the ending. The book suddenly turns to molasses, and it appears he didn't know how to end it. After reading the end notes, I got the impression that he grafted his undergraduate thesis into the ending. He also goes off on some wild tangents (nuclear weapons elimination!) at the very end in essentially a double-I-just-can't-end the book ending. Could have been 4 or 5 stars if he had kept up the pace he started with, but bizarrely it just crumbles at the end.

The fascinating story of the beginnings of the science of epidemiology. When a cholera outbreak strikes a London neighborhood in 1854, Dr. John Snow sets out to gather proof for his theory that the disease is caused by drinking contaminated water, and not by miasma (foul air), which was the popular theory of the time. He famously drew a map showing the location of the victims and the locations of the neighborhood water pumps.The subject is very interesting and the book is well written, but the author meanders quite a bit and is repetitive at times. Towards the end he branches out to discuss the benefits and risks of urban density.

This book is hard to rate. I enjoyed the details about the cholera epidemic and felt like Johnson's narrative style made it much more interesting than it actually was (or than the available evidence allows). But the changing of science/cities/the modern world? Nope. Getting kind of sick of these pseudo-historians trying to be all "X made the whole world different." Also there were a lot of weirdly privileged arguments...e.g. "poor people and rich people live in cities for exactly the same reason...because that's where the action is." Nope. And there was also a racist passage about Native Americans that didn't sit right.

London was the largest city in the world in the 1850s. It had no functional sewage system. This book paints a vivid picture of the sanitary conditions of the time, and gives an overview of the awful impact of cholera, a disease that (we now know) is typically transmitted in contaminated water. When a massive cholera epidemic hit London in 1854, a group of researchers tried to understand what caused the disease and how to stop it.This was a very interesting study of the deductive and inductive processes that led to the new understanding of the critical importance of better sanitation.

A very interesting novel, this work presents its subject matter in a unique way. I thoroughly enjoyed the style with which Steven Johnson tells a story while also demonstrating the scientific and demographic considerations. He incorporates politics, microbiology, and cartography into a good novel, and though he switches points of view and tenses often amid different chapters, he maintains the readers' interests while educating. A solid read.

I read that at least one US university selected The Ghost Map as its 2015 common freshman reading, which prompted me to pick it up for a reread. It's an excellent choice. Johnson models interdisciplinary inquiry as he tells the story of such an enquirer, and the writing is accessible and vivid. I feel odd saying that I 'enjoyed' a book that includes so much discussion of sewage, but nevertheless there it is.

Really a 3.5 star for me. 3/4 of the book was 5 stars but it's all pretty boring and downhill after the mystery is solved. Especially when the author starts referencing The Population Bomb as anything other than BS. In hindsight I would have stopped when he got to talking about the map. BUT the majority of this book is completely fascinating and I'm now obsessed with cholera, 19th century London and sewage systems, and those are words I never thought I'd write.

I have some mixed feelings on this book in the end. Mostly this comes from the last 50 pages or so where the author relates the cholera outbreak and city growth and development to our modern age. It gave me plenty to think about and a good reading list for the future. I was disappointed that he propagated the myth of the Chicag0 1885 cholera epidemic. That's easy research that should have been done.

I knew next to nothing about the 1854 cholera epidemic before picking this book. Now I feel like an expert on the event and the sewer systems. I think my favorite part was the acknowledgement that engineering had as much to do with solving the problem as medicine. My least favorite thing was the epilogue that felt oddly out of place after almost 300 pages of cholera discussion.**I received a copy of this book in exchange for an honest review.**

A facinating medical detective story about the uncovering of the real cause of the horrific cholera outbreak in a Victorian London neighborhood. The author brings the era and its environmental problems to life as he honors the analytical genius of the two main protagonists. A page turner that carries one into another time and place. Public Health history at its best.

In some ways, it felt like it was two books sandwiched together, and I much preferred the narrative part to the areas where Johnson editorializes, even if I do mostly agree with his positions. It was not easy reading -- I definitely didn't race through it -- but worth the effort, I think. I learned a lot of both science and history.

I greatly enjoyed reading this book. I struggle getting through nonfiction, and I wound up having to listen to this book instead of reading it, but despite my hiatus this book has become one of my favorites. I didnt like how it became pro urbanization propaganda, but it did make sense so I guess I cant be too upset about it...

I love the story of Dr. John Snow, the first epidemiologist. I did not like how the book ends with the author arguing points regarding the story's implications to the modern era. I wished the author would have stopped with the well-told story.

Although I really did enjoy this, I wasn't expecting the two hour lecture at the end. It was good and informative and I enjoyed it, but it wasn't really something I needed sprung on me. I docked a star for it.

The subject of this book, is right up my alley. I work in a hospital lab and am fascinated by epidemiology. While I knew a little of John Snow and the London Cholera outbreak, this story went so much more in depth than anything else I've read.

Who would have thought that a book about cholera could be so fascinating? The lively style of writing made this book accessible and entertaining as well as informative. Definitely an author from whom I will now read more.
The best book about poop I've read so far!I should have skipped the epilogue with the babbling about nuclear war, terrorism, and peak energy. It was a horrible ending to an otherwise great book.
I'm kind of annoyed that this was pretty great and then fell apart in the last 2 hours when the author decided they had to make it "relevant" to today's increasing urbanization. :-///

Talk about a timely read. This is something I picked up used before the current disaster, and I remember thinking it was of some interest but more of as an historical artifact. The book deals in some detail, although not overwhelming, with an 1854 cholera outbreak in London and the efforts to figure out what caused it. Cholera of course was well known in that era around the world and caused numerous epidemics, including as recently as 2016-2020 in Yemen. But the prevailing belief (quasi-scientific) in the 1850s and before was that it was caused by 'miasma', i.e. bad air. That notion was hard to shake amongst the cognoscenti of the time. But Dr. John Snow, a name I had not heard before, came up with the theory on the waterborne nature of cholera. He did not even know what in the water would have caused it, turned out to be a bacterium called vibrio cholerae (which actually had been identified by an Italian anatomist around the same time, but that was unknown to Snow). Of course, he was ridiculed despite already being a highly respected physician who was a pioneer in the use of anesthesia. His intense research and close partnership with Rev. Henry Whitehead on the sociological aspects of the epidemic were ground-breaking for the time. And his map of the outbreak (hence the name of book) which he used to illustrate the relationship between contaminated water sources and fatalities became dare I say, a watershed in the use of cartography for epidemiological analysis. From this to the Johns Hopkins site being used for Covid-19. The book written in 2006 is also a paean to the virtues of city living. The solution of the cholera mystery made modern large cities possible, today on a scale unimaginable in the 1850s. And parts of the book are almost an urban worship-fest. Only cities can save us from ourselves, he opines. But in his final chapters on coming epidemics and pandemics he clearly recognizes the threat that has arrived on our doorsteps today. He discusses H5N1 ('bird flu') and the threat it posed back in 2006 but noted the lack of easy transmission from human to human. Well, obviously COVID-19 ('bat flu' or 'lab flu'?) does not follow those ancient rules and suddenly cities look vulnerable again.

The Ghost Map tells the story of how Dr John Snow, a London physician, solved the problem of how to tackle Cholera. Johnson starts his historical tale by setting the scene and in particular detailing the filth and stench of the city and the various professions who cleaned and recycled the city’s waste. In the absence of sewers and formalized waste management, human and animal faeces littered streets and basements. It was the foul-smelling stench – the miasma – of such waste that was thought to spread disease. Snow, however, had a different theory – disease was spread via contaminated water – and most of the book concerns Snow’s work. In particular, the narrative focuses on the 1854 cholera epidemic, its catastrophic outcome on a local community, how by plotting ghosts on a map Snow identified the source of the outbreak, changing both the practice of epidemiology and public infrastructure and public health provision of modern cities globally. It’s an interesting tale, but it is a little uneven in its telling, with an overextended focus on some elements that drifted into repetition, and underdeveloped on others, particularly the public health situation and response, and the evolution of thinking and practice in the years proceeding Snow’s work. And the final chapter on the spread of disease and viruses in the present day, as well as urban development, was a potted attempt to convert the lesson from the nineteenth century to the present that felt like an add-on and speculative. In addition, the lack of Snow’s maps and analysis, especially the key Voronoi one, seemed an important oversight. Overall, an okay read about an interesting case.

It’s the mid-19th century and London is a city. Almost miraculously, a group of people have organised themselves into a class of scavengers, taking on the responsibility of most modern sanitation departments and thus helping two million people get rid of their waste. However, this effort does have some cracks and not all waste is gotten rid of. One particular household’s waste, in particular, is thrown out and lands near a certain pump.The Ghost Map is an account of the John Snow and to a lesser extent, Henry Whitehead’s investigations into a series of chlorea cases (the 1854 Broad Street Chlorea Outbreak) that led to the discovery of a contaminated pump and the dismantling of the miasma theory.Told in seven chapters, each one representing a day, The Ghost Map presents a detailed and sometimes wandering account of how John Snow conducted his investigations. Through this account, the book manages to give the reader a general introduction to who John Snow is, including his work with anaesthesia, as well as why the discovery of water contamination and its relationship to cholera was so important for cities to continue growing without large numbers of deaths.To be honest, the book felt rather longwinded in parts, especially since it has the tendency to digress to other topics (about miasma theory, especially). But I generally enjoyed reading this book. It was heavy, particularly in the current climate, but I think the fact that the cause of transmission of the cholera outbreak could be discovered and stopped gives hope that we can stop future outbreaks of diseases if we approach the situation with an open mind.Overall, I enjoyed it. It’s not the most gripping nonfiction history book that I’ve read but history buffs may be interested in exploring this aspect of medical history.This review was first posted at Eustea Reads

3.25 stars. My high school friend lent me this book almost a decade ago and I just didn't read it because it intimidated me. But I'm STRONGER now and I finally read it! 💪I am very glad I read this as an audiobook because it would've been much harder for me to get through otherwise. I'm personally drawn to many things at once and would have probably put this down in favor of something else because it's dense with information and while well-researched and interesting, it's not exactly so riveting, I'd drop everything else. But I wanted to read this now and understand how it might relate to what's happening in the world today, especially in high-population cities.I didn't understand why so many "experts" at the time didn't take to theories of mass infection by ingesting water from the same location rather than "because it smells so bad." 😒 I do, however, know that what we consider common sense today was built by people who had to sway public opinions with what, at the time, was groundbreaking leaps in logic. "The virus that causes such international panic does not exist yet" 👀"Some experts think a pandemic on the order of 1918 is a near inevitability" 👀👀"But we'll have the tools at our disposal to deal with the emerging threats if we're smart enough to deploy them." 👀👀👀👀👀👀👀It's a whole different animal to have a virus passed from human to human so easily and carelessly compared to diseases that arose from poor living conditions and a lack of sanitary resources. Both nightmares, both harbingers of mass death, both serving as catalysts for advancement in vaccine medicine and genetic composition analysis.

Talk about a timely read. This is something I picked up used before the current disaster, and I remember thinking it was of some interest but more of as an historical artifact. The book deals in some detail, although not overwhelming, with an 1854 cholera outbreak in London and the efforts to figure out what caused it. Cholera of course was well known in that era around the world and caused numerous epidemics, including as recently as 2016-2020 in Yemen. But the prevailing belief (quasi-scientific) in the 1850s and before was that it was caused by 'miasma', i.e. bad air. That notion was hard to shake amongst the cognoscenti of the time. But Dr. John Snow, a name I had not heard before, came up with the theory on the waterborne nature of cholera. He did not even know what in the water would have caused it, turned out to be a bacterium called vibrio cholerae (which actually had been identified by an Italian anatomist around the same time, but that was unknown to Snow). Of course, he was ridiculed despite already being a highly respected physician who was a pioneer in the use of anesthesia. His intense research and close partnership with Rev. Henry Whitehead on the sociological aspects of the epidemic were ground-breaking for the time. And his map of the outbreak (hence the name of book) which he used to illustrate the relationship between contaminated water sources and fatalities became dare I say, a watershed in the use of cartography for epidemiological analysis. From this to the Johns Hopkins site being used for Covid-19. The book written in 2006 is also a paean to the virtues of city living. The solution of the cholera mystery made modern large cities possible, today on a scale unimaginable in the 1850s. And parts of the book are almost an urban worship-fest. Only cities can save us from ourselves, he opines. But in his final chapters on coming epidemics and pandemics he clearly recognizes the threat that has arrived on our doorsteps today. He discusses H5N1 ('bird flu') and the threat it posed back in 2006 but noted the lack of easy transmission from human to human. Well, obviously COVID-19 ('bat flu' or 'lab flu'?) does not follow those ancient rules and suddenly cities look vulnerable again.

The Ghost Map tells the story of how Dr John Snow, a London physician, solved the problem of how to tackle Cholera. Johnson starts his historical tale by setting the scene and in particular detailing the filth and stench of the city and the various professions who cleaned and recycled the city’s waste. In the absence of sewers and formalized waste management, human and animal faeces littered streets and basements. It was the foul-smelling stench – the miasma – of such waste that was thought to spread disease. Snow, however, had a different theory – disease was spread via contaminated water – and most of the book concerns Snow’s work. In particular, the narrative focuses on the 1854 cholera epidemic, its catastrophic outcome on a local community, how by plotting ghosts on a map Snow identified the source of the outbreak, changing both the practice of epidemiology and public infrastructure and public health provision of modern cities globally. It’s an interesting tale, but it is a little uneven in its telling, with an overextended focus on some elements that drifted into repetition, and underdeveloped on others, particularly the public health situation and response, and the evolution of thinking and practice in the years proceeding Snow’s work. And the final chapter on the spread of disease and viruses in the present day, as well as urban development, was a potted attempt to convert the lesson from the nineteenth century to the present that felt like an add-on and speculative. In addition, the lack of Snow’s maps and analysis, especially the key Voronoi one, seemed an important oversight. Overall, an okay read about an interesting case.

It’s the mid-19th century and London is a city. Almost miraculously, a group of people have organised themselves into a class of scavengers, taking on the responsibility of most modern sanitation departments and thus helping two million people get rid of their waste. However, this effort does have some cracks and not all waste is gotten rid of. One particular household’s waste, in particular, is thrown out and lands near a certain pump.The Ghost Map is an account of the John Snow and to a lesser extent, Henry Whitehead’s investigations into a series of chlorea cases (the 1854 Broad Street Chlorea Outbreak) that led to the discovery of a contaminated pump and the dismantling of the miasma theory.Told in seven chapters, each one representing a day, The Ghost Map presents a detailed and sometimes wandering account of how John Snow conducted his investigations. Through this account, the book manages to give the reader a general introduction to who John Snow is, including his work with anaesthesia, as well as why the discovery of water contamination and its relationship to cholera was so important for cities to continue growing without large numbers of deaths.To be honest, the book felt rather longwinded in parts, especially since it has the tendency to digress to other topics (about miasma theory, especially). But I generally enjoyed reading this book. It was heavy, particularly in the current climate, but I think the fact that the cause of transmission of the cholera outbreak could be discovered and stopped gives hope that we can stop future outbreaks of diseases if we approach the situation with an open mind.Overall, I enjoyed it. It’s not the most gripping nonfiction history book that I’ve read but history buffs may be interested in exploring this aspect of medical history.This review was first posted at Eustea Reads

I am not entirely sure how I ended up reading a book about a 19th century cholera epidemic. It must have been recommended to me because I like Victorian mysteries. He did it through a combination of scientific observation and sociological study, using a now-famous map to trace the spread of the disease. In the end, the handle was removed from the famous Broad Street pump which had been the vector for the particularly virulent strain of cholera that wiped out much of Soho. His evidence contributed to the development of the London sewer system, a massive engineering project that was way ahead of its time, and set the pattern for modern urban sanitation systems. The book finishes up with a discussion of how these systems basically make civilization sustainable on the planet because dense cities are the most efficient and sustainable way for people to live (if they have proper plumbing, clearly!)So, now I guess I'm going to have find a book about the guy who built the London sewers!

Mind blown! The story took a bit to get going and there are definitely some dry parts. But wow was it packed with fascinating information. We can now look down our noses at the ignorance of our forefathers trying to cure illness and disease with poultices and castor oil and smoke. But what will our great great great grandchildren say about our “advanced medical knowledge” today? We do the best we can with what we’ve got, just like every human civilization has done. My ah-ha moment was right near the middle. Of course we now know that cholera was spread by London’s water supply in 1853. But they didn’t then. And many people tried to figure it out with logic and experiment. A lot of amazing scientific hero’s stayed in London’s Broad Street even though staying might mean certain death. Many people in that time drank water. But things were changing. Many of our forefathers survived because they chose alcohol over water. It was better to die from cirrhosis of the liver at 40 than microbial diseases at 20. In order to tolerate alcohol our bodies need to produce the enzymes alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH) and aldehyde dehydrogenase (ALDH) from chromosome 4. Not everyone has the genetics to digest alcohol. And many years ago, fewer people could do this. With humans moving from rural to urban centres we created some waste related issues for ourselves. The more concentrated the human population, the dirtier our water supplies became, the greater chance of water born diseases. Hence people that could digest alcohol had a higher probability of living through microbial disease and procreate. Whereas the ones that couldn’t digest alcohol, stuck with water and didn’t live long enough to procreate. This in turn bottlenecked our Caucasian genetics to be able to tolerate alcohol easily. And here was my ah-ha moment. A historical culture that didn’t urbanize and bottleneck their genetics was the indigenous cultures of Australia and North America. These cultures are well known in today’s culture for their issues with alcohol. And Johnson theorizes that their rural hunting and gathering not only preventing them from developing immunity to many urban diseases but may have contributed to their genetic issues with alcohol. A very thought provoking theory. I really enjoyed the journey Snow and Whitehead went through to figure out the problem of cholera. It was also interesting to see the coincidences that prevented cholera from doing even more damage.I’m sure this book isn’t for everyone. But I thoroughly enjoyed it!
